conversations.content: Please note that this story contains spoilers for chapter 10 of the main campaign, as well as the ＂Dawn of Dragalia＂ event.
I'm ALBERIUS! If you're not afraid of my DRAGONBLOOD, then COME AT MEEE!
Hah! Yaaah! Hee-yah!
Come now, what are you doing? I said you could play outside AFTER you finished cleaning your room!
Is Alberius not back yet, Mom? He's still off fighting with Dad?
That's right. And if you clean your room and be a good boy, I'm sure they'll both be back very soon.
But I haaaate cleaning my room... C'mon, everybody! Let's go play more!
Honestly! When the hero finally returns, I'm going to have him give that child a stern talking-to.
ROOOOAR!
Victory is ours! Let any who still do not fear the dragonblood step up and face me!
We can't take any more of this... Retreat! RETREAT!
We did it! We won the day!
I'm shocked at how easy it was to repel the Dyrenell Empire! Three cheers for the hero of the day, Alberius!
We were merely lucky our strategy played out so well this time. And remember, our war with the Empire isn't over yet. Let's make sure we don't get complacent.
Ever with your own spoonful of humble pie, eh, Alberius? C'mon, let's hurry back to the village and tell everyone of our hero's courageous deeds!
Our hero...
At a base and village allied with Alberius in South Grastaea...
But then, who should appear like a bolt from the blue, but the wielder of the sacred sword, the great Alberius!
As the mighty hero cut through wave after wave of enemies, the imperials all turned tail and ran like cravens!
All that to say, we kicked their tails from dusk to dawn! Bwaaa ha ha ha!
Your tale remains as gallant as the first three times you told it today.
Yaaay, Dad! Tell it again!
Oh, you know I will! Our hero Alberius is the most amazing man I've ever met, and I'm going to sing his praises until my voice is gone!
Hah, you exaggerate, my friend. I'll never keep pace with the tales of my exploits if you continue those stories.
Do you see?! Alberius has achieved glory beyond all measure, yet is humble as a lamb in spring! Truly, he is the savior we have all been waiting for!
Even the Other won't be able to stand against us with Alberius at our side!
I fear that may prove difficult.
All right, who's interrupting me in the middle of a story?!
That was I, good sir. I am an emissary of the Faerie King himself, and come bearing a message for the wielder of Dragalia.
O great hero Alberius! Our king beseeches you to bring your sacred sword and might to our Faerie Kingdom!
The Faerie Kingdom? Yes, I remember hearing about that place from Midgardsormr at some point...
It is a kingdom in North Grastaea hidden away from the world through magic. Evidently, none may enter without express permission of the faeries.
Wait, all the way up in North Grastaea? It'd take ages to get there from here!
If your ultimate goal is to defeat the Other, you may simply consider it a necessary expenditure of time for the cause.
And if I make this trip to your kingdom, what will you do to aid our cause?
I am told our Faerie King will confer upon you a secret rite which will permit you to defeat the Other.
What manner of secret rite?
I am but His Majesty's humble messenger, and not informed as to the particulars.
Then tell us what you DO know, as vague as it may be.
It is a rite known as the Blood Casket.
With it, anything can be sealed away. However, it is not a technique to be used by the fainthearted.
And to seal away a creature as strong as the Other will take a person of exemplary physical and mental ability— a person much like you, Alberius.
However, once the Blood Casket is used, the caster will suffer an endless agony akin to death itself—or so I am told.
Well that's frightening.
I can guarantee the magic's effects are great enough to be worthy of the pain.
Thought you didn't know the details about this, friend.
That is true—yet I know the Faerie King body and soul, so believe me when I say he is not the sort who would dispatch an envoy to a foreign nation on a whim.
His position prevents him from easily leaving our kingdom, but his feelings of disgust for the Other's crimes are quite the same as everyone's.
Yet with all due respect, feelings alone will not deliver victory against the fiend. If you would win, you must use the rite.
I have said all I came here to say, and must now return to the kingdom. And while hope you will see fit to accompany me, I will not coerce you.
The rite is meaningless if you lack the will to use it. The choice is up to you.
If your resolve to defeat the Other stands firm, pray make your way to us anon.
What will you do, Alberius?
Hmm...
Don't go, Alberius! If you leave, the Empire will slaughter us!
Please! We need you!
...Don't worry. I won't abandon you.
Though the faeries claim there's no way to beat the Other without their rite, they offer no more than their words as proof.
I have fought and bled beside all of you, and I believe in the power of that bond far more than some pretty talk!
We may lack this secret rite of theirs, but if we combine our strength—all of us—I know we can defeat the Other. So put your trust in me and follow!
Huzzah for Alberius the savior!
Huzzah, Alberius! Huzzah, Alberius!
Is this truly the correct path, Alberius?
I told you, don't worry. Er, and I hate to ask this, but could you tell everyone to keep this business about the faeries' secret rite to themselves?
I don't want to cause undue anxiety for anyone else.
Where are you going?
You worry too much, Midgardsormr. I'm just overheated from all the loud talking. I'm going to get a little night air.
Alberius...
Welcome back, Alberius.
The village... What happened to it?!
A detachment of imperials attacked it while you were fighting in the rearguard to secure our retreat. By the time we returned here ourselves, it was already too late.
We drove off the occupying imperial force, but the damage to the village is severe. We have no choice but to abandon it.
I see...
What happened out there, Alberius?
I fought the Other.
What?! Explain!
After I took on the role of holding back the enemy to buy time to retreat...
The Lake Deira front line Hours prior
Advance, loyal soldiers of the Other! Bring down the hammer of his judgment upon those who would rise against our mighty Dyrenell Empire!
Dys fahr Dyrenell!
Damn, look at their numbers... We're going to be overwhelmed!
A large number of enemy reinforcements have appeared to the northeast, sir! Requesting immediate reinforcements to prevent the collapse of the front lines!
The imperial army appears to be approaching from the south, as well. What will our course be, Alberius?
We must withdraw. I want everyone to follow Midgardsormr through the forest to the west and make for our base.
And what will you do?
I will take up the rear and stop the enemy in their tracks. I will protect you all!
I know better than to try and sway you when your mind is decided. But I must warn you, Alberius: Do not die on us.
I've not plans of doing so today.
Inform all forces immediately.
The allied army will proceed through the woods west of this location and withdraw to our garrison. All troops, follow me!
Time for me to be off.
Come at me, Imperial scum! Haaah!
Uwaaagh!
Blimey, this guy's attackin' us all on his lonesome! Must be that Alberius dog we've heard so much about!
He's a bloody idiot with a death wish, so let's grant it and go home already!
I shall take you all on at once!
Graaagh!
*pant* *pant* What's wrong? That all you got?
What the...? He's just one man! How can this be happening?!
This guy ain't human—we brought enough soldiers to take out an entire CITY!
Not human? Heh. A fitting turn of phrase.
Who the hell are you?!
Cardinal Lambert... Or should I say, Morsayati?!
It has been some time, Alberius. As the chosen hero of the sacred sword, word of your commendable deeds has found its way to me.
Then prepare to witness my deeds firsthand, and know they will be the final thing you ever see!
Aaaaah ha ha ha! Wonderful! The hero has added comic timing to his list of meritorious traits!
Aaaaaaaugh!
Damnation! He killed the hero in one blow!
It matters not what caliber of hero you are; in the end, you are still a mere human. Opposing me was folly from the start.
I'm...not finished yet...
You live? Fascinating. Well, no matter. There won't be a second time.
You're right—because there's no way I'll let you hit me with that again! Haaaah!
Heh, I see ＂hero＂ is not merely a title. Your sword might even reach me someday...but that just makes you all the more pitiable.
What?
Your power has begun to transcend human limits. You are deviating from the way of this world, and transforming into a being of...this side.
Fiends! And so many!
Heh heh heh. Let us see now if you are a hero for true. Go, my servants!
There's no end to them!
Has the truth begun to sink in now, hero? Do you see how very alone you are?
You may have thought to fight alongside your comrades, but such notions are naught but a fevered delusion.
That's not true!
Then look about you. Do you see anyone? Any hide or hair of comrades with whom you could stand together?
None of the fellows you so desperately try to protect can keep up with your strength.
Have you not realized it in your heart? The comrades fighting alongside you are nothing more than an impediment!
Enough of your pretensions, Morsayati! I have defeated all of your minions, and now your turn has come!
Do you really believe that trifling number of pawns was my final gambit?
This is the difference between us: I am o'erflowing with minions such that I can use them and toss them aside, while you are utterly alone.
Hrk!
It would be a simple matter indeed to set my fiends upon you and watch them put you in the ground, but I will beg off.
What is your game here, devil?
Surrender to me, solitary hero. Surrender...and then serve me.
You know the answer without my even having to speak the words!
You would refuse readily now, perhaps. But next time, who can say?
Explain yourself!
You will come to learn the extent to which humans are selfish, foolish creatures.
In the near future, you will be betrayed by humans and have them reject you. Such is the fate of all with great power.
Heh heh. What a spectacle it will be to see what one extolled as a hero chooses. I look forward to the next opportunity to speak with you.
My...choice.
That is quite the tale.
At any rate, I am relieved to see you safe. You must be tired—and while the village has been destroyed, we still have a provisional barracks at the ready.
...Alberius?
It's Alberius! The hero who protects us all!
You are from the village...
Why didn't you protect my dad?!
Dad said you were amazing! He said you'd beat the Other and save everybody!
But now he's gone! Why didn't you save him?! Why?!
What's going on over here?
You! You were supposed to protect our village! Why didn't you?!
We only got attacked because of you! Better that you had never come!
How dare you!
Enough, Midgardsormr.
I'm sorry, everyone. I thought I could save you all, but I wasn't strong enough. And now you are paying the price for that failure.
I swear to you this: I WILL make amends. Pray just give me a little time.
Hear me well, Alberius...
It is unwise of you to apologize to them. Doing so only solidifies the false notion that you are somehow to blame.
The villagers are caught up in their emotions now, but with time, they will regain their normal sense of judgment. You need not shoulder that guilt.
It's...
You will come to learn the extent to which humans are selfish, foolish creatures.
In the near future, you will be betrayed by humans and have them reject you. Such is the fate of all with great power.
...It's the fate of all with great power, perhaps.
Fate? Just what do you mean?
My apologies; I am tired, and my mind goes where it will. I'll go get some rest in those barracks you mentioned.
Something is amiss with you, Alberius...
This guy's still wet behind the ears! How the hell is he beating us?!
Hraah!
Ngaaah!
Welcome home, Alberius. It seems you repelled the imperials alone yet again.
I just took the most appropriate steps to win. But enough on that—I have a favor I need to ask you.
Speak, and let us see if I will grant it.
I want to leave the allied forces in your command for a while.
You can't mean to...
Yes. I make for the Faerie Kingdom.
You recall how I fought the Other recently? The power I saw on display that day was overwhelming. I cannot defeat him as I am now.
And so your mind turns to the sorcery the faerie emissary spoke of. But as you said, we have no basis for believing them.
What happened to the power of the bonds you forged fighting at the side of others? Would you discard them in favor of some baseless promise?
I will face down the Other by myself; if there is something I can do to increase my chance of victory, I must seize it.
Then you lack faith in your companions.
You misunderstand. My fighting alone is simply the best chance for victory.
Do not make so close a companion of your hubris, Alberius. It does not watch your back as I do!
Hrk?! Midgardsormr?
Come at me, Alberius, that I might stamp this arrogance out of you!
Where is this coming from?!
If you think to fight the Other alone, I would first put you to the test!
...All right. But I don't want to hear any complaints when I beat you!
THIS is your best? If this is all you have to offer, you ought to spend time reflecting on the foolishness of fighting alone!
*pant* *pant* *pant*
I am the victor. Are you convinced now?
How could I be?
Why do you not put your faith in us? Are you trying to suggest that we are no longer your comrades?
Not at all.
It is BECAUSE I have faith in my comrades that I will learn the faerie's secret rite.
I will defeat the Other—alone. If what the faeries claim is true, their magic will make it possible.
They claimed it is a power no ordinary person can handle; that only one of your caliber could successfully seal the Other.
Supposing that this rite actually CAN defeat the Other, then—in theory— you could best the creature alone.
But theory does not bear the weight of practicality, and I cannot assent to you fighting by yourself on such a basis.
The Other's power is immense—far beyond anything that could be surmounted with sheer numbers. I'd rather not have us make unnecessary sacrifices.
You may not intend your words to carry this meaning, but they sound as though you consider us but a hindrance.
That's not what I'm trying to say. All of you have a role—a critical one— that I cannot hope to manage myself.
What do you speak of?
I can defeat the Other by myself, but I cannot do what comes next: The building of a peaceful world.
After I'm gone, I wish to leave the world in everyone's capable hands.
After you're gone?
Apparently, using the rite means one will suffer a pain equal to that of death itself— a pain that continues without end.
Obviously I'm not planning on dying any time soon—so when I say ＂when I'm gone,＂ I don't mean right away. But I'm talking about things beyond that.
Still, this is a watershed moment, one when we determine if the world I seek and hope for can be realized!
I see.
That part of you is ever unchanging; it has been so since first we met.
Then I've convinced you?
You have not. However, you clearly will not hear what I have to say.
Ha ha ha! Perhaps you're right, at that. Regardless, Windwyrm, I would ask you to abide my selfishness for a little longer.
I suppose I've no choice in the matter. Now go, before others can question you.
That day, Alberius set out on a journey to the Faerie Kingdom.
The allied forces were shaken by the sudden departure of their hero, but structure was maintained thanks to Midgardsormr.
Thus did three months pass, absent the hero.
Southern Grastaea Garrison Dormitory
You jest overmuch, having just returned from the Faerie Kingdom. If the price of this Blood Casket magic is what you say, then its use is out of the question.
We knew this right from the very start, didn't we, Midgardsormr? The one who invokes the rite will suffer a pain akin to endless death.
No, Alberius. It is not that simple. Do you truly understand what you hope to do?
I understand perfectly well. How could I have explained it to you otherwise?
That is not what I mean. You do not realize the meaning of the cost you just described.
...The cost of sealing the soul of the Other into your very own blood.
The matter is not only a problem for you; the effects will extend down to all who share your bloodline.
It is a curse that will taint all who come after you forever—and it means the Other will live on inside your descendants.
If that is necessary, so be it.
Then you would sacrifice your entire future for the sake of the world?!
My friend...
Do you remember when I said we faced a watershed moment before I left for the Faerie Kingdom?
Yes. You claimed you could defeat the Other alone, but that the work of creating a peaceful world after that was something you could not do yourself.
You know, Midgardsormr, after the battle with the Other is over, I'm going to found my own kingdom and have children.
Well, this is rather sudden.
I speak of the future, Midgardsormr— a future I have no intention of discarding.
I told you I want to leave the world that is to come in everyone's capable hands.
Defeating the Other is not the end. We still require a light to guide people— a hope so they can come together as one.
I will become that hope, and then my children will see it carried on.
But if you use the Blood Casket, your children will also end up inheriting the soul of the Other.
I understand well the danger this course of action poses to my descendants.
Then why?
Because I believe my offspring will never give in to the soul of the Other.
I know there is risk; I know one of them could even have their own soul taken over by that fell creature.
But I also know that my descendants will have the strength to endure, unyielding, until the Other is eradicated utterly.
Have you any idea the magnitude of what you are saying?
You are forcing your descendants to be heroes—demanding it of them, in essence.
I imagine anyone descended from me will be willing to take up that mantle.
Hmph. You burst with parental pride.
Of course, first things first, I need to find myself a partner.
For you, that may be a task even greater than bringing down Morsayati.
Well that's no good. Have any ideas? Like maybe you could show up and—
From that day on, Alberius rejoined the allied forces and led them in battle against the Empire. Thus did the struggle between them—and that between Alberius and the Other—intensify.
This is all a bit showy, don't you think?
On the contrary, I think some flash will serve you well here. The more attention you earn, the more it will raise everyone's spirits.
If that's what you think, I will trust you.
The fighting will be ever more fierce from this point out, so anything I can do to aid our cause must be done.
Just so. Now, hero, let everyone behold your gallant visage.
Very well.
Armed with fresh resolve and clad in white armor, Alberius fought at the fore once more.
The dizzying array of heroic deeds he performed have been handed down through many generations as anecdotes of his valor.
With nigh-godlike strength, he continued to drive imperial forces back, and ere long arrived at his fateful confrontation with the Other.
However, there exist none who beheld their epic clash personally; the hero fought his nemesis alone.
Thus did Alberius strike a resounding victory and bring down the Other—and it was this result alone that was passed down as legend.
His victory assured, Alberius founded a kingdom in South Grastaea and was blessed with a child.
The great hero's descendants thus became new hope for the people, and for generations ruled South Grastaea as its monarchs.
Until his final moments, Alberius was a beacon of hope and a hero to his people. And so did his offspring inherit his determination to be that selfsame hope for all.
That heroic bloodline continues to this very day.
Those are the protocols for the restoration. Given the current situation in the nation, this is likely our best course of action.
I'm always impressed at how you're able to anticipate things so far ahead, Brother.
Well, you know I am ALSO coming up with these protocols, so be certain to include me when doling out praise.
Oh, um, right. You...never fail to impress.
Enough tomfoolery. Chelle. Those travel preparations of yours—are they finished?
It takes time for a lady to prepare, and all the more so on a long journey.
I have also received reports suggesting you might be plotting some sort of meddlesome project of your own?
Whatever could you mean?
I won't investigate closely—for now. But refrain from doing anything that would add to our current difficulties.
I will do my level best not to cause you any trouble, dear brother.
Leaving that aside, I wanted to bring up the matter of the food distribution to the villages we previously discussed...
The hero's bloodline... The descendants of Alberius...
Your will certainly has been passed on in these young people.
I shall serve as your agent and watch over the hope you bequeathed unto your kin.
It appears I shall accompany you just a little longer, Alberius...
